High-risk AI systems should only be placed on the Union market, put into service or used 
if they comply with certain mandatory requirements. Those requirements should ensure 
that high-risk AI systems available in the Union or whose output is otherwise used in the 
Union do not pose unacceptable risks to important Union public interests as recognised and 
protected by Union law. On the basis of the New Legislative Framework, as clarified in 
the Commission notice “The ‘Blue Guide’ on the implementation of EU product rules 
2022”20, the general rule is that more than one legal act of Union harmonisation 
legislation, such as Regulations (EU) 2017/74521 and (EU) 2017/74622 of the European 
Parliament and of the Council or Directive 2006/42/EC of the European Parliament and 
of the Council23, may be applicable to one product, since the making available or putting 
into service can take place only when the product complies with all applicable Union 
harmonisation legislation. To ensure consistency and avoid unnecessary administrative 
burdens or costs, providers of a product that contains one or more high-risk AI systems, 
to which the requirements of this Regulation and of the Union harmonisation legislation 
listed in an annex to this Regulation apply, should have flexibility with regard to 
operational decisions on how to ensure compliance of a product that contains one or 
more AI systems with all applicable requirements of the Union harmonisation legislation 
in an optimal manner. AI systems identified as high-risk should be limited to those that 
have a significant harmful impact on the health, safety and fundamental rights of persons 
in the Union and such limitation should minimise any potential restriction to international 
trade.

OJ C 247, 29.6.2022, p. 1.

As an AI language model, I cannot provide legal advice or interpretation of the EU AI Act. However, I can provide a general overview of the prohibitions on biometric categorisation systems under the EU AI Act.

The EU AI Act prohibits the use of biometric categorisation systems in public spaces unless certain conditions are met. Biometric categorisation systems are defined as AI systems that process biometric data for the purpose of uniquely identifying a natural person or for attributing a particular characteristic or categorisation to a natural person.

Under the EU AI Act, the use of biometric categorisation systems in public spaces is prohibited unless:

1. The use is necessary for reasons of substantial public interest, such as ensuring public safety or preventing terrorist attacks.

2. The use is strictly necessary and proportionate to achieve the intended purpose.

3. The use is subject to appropriate safeguards to protect the rights and freedoms of individuals, including the right to privacy and data protection.

4. The use is transparent and individuals are informed about the use of the system and their rights.

5. The use is subject to human oversight and intervention.

6. The use is subject to regular testing, monitoring, and evaluation to ensure compliance with the above conditions.

It is important to note that the EU AI Act is not yet in force and is still subject to approval by the European Parliament and Council. Once approved, it will become law in all EU member states.

and proportionate safeguards and conditions in relation to the use in accordance with the

in publicly accessible spaces shall be authorised only if the law enforcement authority 
has completed a fundamental rights impact assessment as provided for in Article 27 and 
has registered the system in the EU database according to Article 49. However, in duly 
justified cases of urgency, the use of such systems may be commenced without the 
registration in the EU database, provided that such registration is completed without 
undue delay.

question: As a Member State, what immediate actions must I take if the Commission justifies a measure on an AI system, especially regarding market withdrawal and compliance?

a Member State finds that although a high-risk AI system complies with this Regulation, it

other aspects of public interest protection, it shall require the relevant operator to take all

given to AI systems presenting a risk to vulnerable groups. Where risks to fundamental 
rights are identified, the market surveillance authority shall also inform and fully 
cooperate with the relevant national public authorities or bodies referred to in Article 
77(1). The relevant operators shall cooperate as necessary with the market surveillance 
authority and with the other national public authorities or bodies referred to in Article 
77(1).
Where, in the course of that evaluation, the market surveillance authority or, where 
applicable the market surveillance authority in cooperation with the national public 
authority referred to in Article 77(1), finds that the AI system does not comply with the 
requirements and obligations laid down in this Regulation, it shall without undue delay 
require the relevant operator to take all appropriate corrective actions to bring the AI 
system into compliance, to withdraw the AI system from the market, or to recall it within a 
period the market surveillance authority may prescribe, and in any event within the 
shorter of 15 working days, or as provided for in the relevant Union harmonisation 
legislation.
The market surveillance authority shall inform the relevant notified body accordingly. 
Article 18 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 shall apply to the measures referred to in the 
second subparagraph of this paragraph.
3.

to its national territory, it shall inform the Commission and the other Member States 
without undue delay of the results of the evaluation and of the actions which it has 
required the operator to take.

question: As a law enforcement agency, how can we apply remote biometric identification for serious criminal offences while ensuring compliance with the EU Regulation, especially considering potential risks to privacy and civil liberties?
reference_answer: The Regulation states that the list of criminal offences provided is based on the 32 criminal offences listed in the Council Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA, and that the recourse to ‘real-time’ remote biometric identification could be necessary and proportionate to varying degrees for the practical pursuit of the localisation or identification of a perpetrator or suspect of the different criminal offences listed.
reference_context:

Moreover, the list of criminal offences provided in an annex to this Regulation is based 
on the 32 criminal offences listed in the Council Framework Decision 2002/584/JHA18, 
taking into account that some of those offences are, in practice, likely to be more relevant 
than others, in that the recourse to ‘real-time’ remote biometric identification could, 
foreseeably, be necessary and proportionate to highly varying degrees for the practical 
pursuit of the localisation or identification of a perpetrator or suspect of the different 
criminal offences listed and having regard to the likely differences in the seriousness, 
probability and scale of the harm or possible negative consequences. An imminent threat 
to life or the physical safety of natural persons could also result from a serious 
disruption of critical infrastructure, as defined in Article 2, point (4) of Directive (EU) 
2022/2557 of the European Parliament and of the Council19, where the disruption or 
destruction of such critical infrastructure would result in an imminent threat to life or 
the physical safety of a person, including through serious harm to the provision of basic 
supplies to the population or to the exercise of the core function of the State. In addition, 
this Regulation should preserve the ability for law enforcement, border control, 
immigration or asylum authorities to carry out identity checks in the presence of the 
person concerned in accordance with the conditions set out in Union and national law 
for such checks. In particular, law enforcement, border control, immigration or asylum 
authorities should be able to use information systems, in accordance with Union or 
national law, to identify persons who, during an identity check, either refuse to be 
identified or are unable to state or prove their identity, without being required by this 
Regulation to obtain prior authorisation. This could be, for example, a person involved 
in a crime, being unwilling, or unable due to an accident or a medical condition, to 
disclose their identity to law enforcement authorities.
18

warrant and the surrender procedures between Member States (OJ L 190, 18.7.2002, p. 
1).

This assessment should include an evaluation of the accuracy and reliability of the technology, the potential for misuse or abuse, and the impact on individuals' rights.

2. Ensure compliance with the EU Regulation: The EU Regulation on the protection of personal data (GDPR) sets strict rules on the collection, processing, and storage of personal data. Any remote biometric identification system must comply with these rules, including obtaining explicit consent from individuals, providing transparency about the data collected and processed, and ensuring the security of the data.

3. Limit the use of biometric data: Biometric data is sensitive personal data that requires special protection. Law enforcement agencies should limit the use of biometric data to serious criminal offenses and ensure that the data is not used for any other purpose.

4. Implement strict access controls: Access to biometric data should be strictly controlled and limited to authorized personnel. Law enforcement agencies should also implement robust security measures to prevent unauthorized access or data breaches.

5. Provide transparency and accountability: Law enforcement agencies should be transparent about their use of remote biometric identification and provide individuals with clear information about the data collected and processed. They should also establish clear accountability mechanisms to ensure that any misuse or abuse of the technology is identified and addressed promptly.

6. Involve stakeholders: Law enforcement agencies should involve stakeholders, including civil society organizations, privacy experts, and data protection authorities, in the development and implementation of any remote biometric identification system. This will help to ensure that the system is designed and implemented in a way that respects privacy and civil liberties.

question: As a notifying authority, how can I ensure impartiality with conformity assessment bodies while maintaining confidentiality and avoiding conflicts of interest?
reference_answer: Notifying authorities shall be established, organised and operated in such a way that no conflict of interest arises with conformity assessment bodies, and that the objectivity and impartiality of their activities are safeguarded.

conflict of interest arises with conformity assessment bodies, and that the objectivity and 
impartiality of their activities are safeguarded.
4.
Notifying authorities shall be organised in such a way that decisions relating to the 
notification of conformity assessment bodies are taken by competent persons different 
from those who carried out the assessment of those bodies.
5.
Notifying authorities shall offer or provide neither any activities that conformity 
assessment bodies perform, nor any consultancy services on a commercial or competitive 
basis.
6.
Notifying authorities shall safeguard the confidentiality of the information that they obtain, 
in accordance with Article 78.
7.
Notifying authorities shall have an adequate number of competent personnel at their 
disposal for the proper performance of their tasks. Competent personnel shall have the 
necessary expertise, where applicable, for their function, in fields such as information 
technologies, AI and law, including the supervision of fundamental rights.
agent_answer:
As an AI language model, I do not have personal beliefs or biases. However, here are some general guidelines that can help ensure impartiality with conformity assessment bodies while maintaining confidentiality and avoiding conflicts of interest:

1. Establish clear policies and procedures for selecting and evaluating conformity assessment bodies. These policies should be transparent and based on objective criteria, such as technical competence, experience, and accreditation.

2. Avoid any conflicts of interest by ensuring that the notifying authority does not have any financial or other interests in the conformity assessment bodies that it selects or evaluates.

3. Maintain confidentiality by ensuring that all information provided by the conformity assessment bodies is kept confidential and only shared with authorized personnel.

4. Ensure that the conformity assessment bodies are independent and free from any undue influence or pressure from the notifying authority.

5. Regularly monitor and evaluate the performance of the conformity assessment bodies to ensure that they are meeting the required standards and maintaining their impartiality.

6. Provide training and guidance to conformity assessment bodies on the requirements and expectations of the notifying authority to ensure that they understand their roles and responsibilities.

7. Encourage feedback and complaints from stakeholders to identify any potential issues or concerns with the performance of the conformity assessment bodies.

77(1). The relevant operators shall cooperate as necessary with the market surveillance

shorter of 15 working days, or as provided for in the relevant Union harmonisation 
legislation.

Article 18 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1020 shall apply to the measures referred to in the 
second subparagraph of this paragraph.

to its national territory, it shall inform the Commission and the other Member States 
without undue delay of the results of the evaluation and of the actions which it has

Designated representatives (DRs) are individuals or organizations appointed by manufacturers or importers to act on their behalf in regulatory matters. The purpose of DRs is to ensure that the manufacturer or importer complies with the regulatory requirements of the country where they are selling their products.

DRs interact with national authorities by submitting regulatory documents, responding to inquiries, and representing the manufacturer or importer in regulatory matters. They also interact with stakeholders such as distributors, customers, and suppliers to ensure that the products are compliant with the regulatory requirements.

The role of DRs is critical in ensuring regulatory consistency as they act as a bridge between the manufacturer or importer and the regulatory authorities. They ensure that the products meet the regulatory requirements and are safe for use by the consumers.

As a compliance officer, it is important to work closely with the DRs to ensure that the regulatory requirements are met. This includes reviewing the regulatory documents submitted by the DRs, conducting audits, and providing guidance on regulatory matters.

In summary, DRs play a crucial role in ensuring regulatory consistency by acting as a liaison between the manufacturer or importer and the regulatory authorities. They interact with national authorities and stakeholders to ensure that the products meet the regulatory requirements and are safe for use by the consumers.

1. Energy Efficiency: Implement energy-efficient algorithms and hardware to reduce the energy consumption of your AI model. You can also optimize the model's architecture and parameters to reduce the computational load.

2. Data Efficiency: Use data-efficient training techniques such as transfer learning, data augmentation, and active learning to reduce the amount of training data required for your model.

3. Fairness and Bias: Evaluate your model for fairness and bias by analyzing the training data and testing the model on diverse datasets. Use techniques such as adversarial training and counterfactual analysis to mitigate bias.

4. Robustness: Test your model for robustness against adversarial attacks and other forms of input perturbations. Use techniques such as adversarial training and input sanitization to improve the model's robustness.

5. Transparency: Provide transparency into your model's decision-making process by explaining the model's predictions and highlighting the important features. Use techniques such as LIME and SHAP to generate explanations.

6. Continual Learning: Implement continual learning techniques to enable your model to adapt to changing environments and data distributions. Use techniques such as online learning and meta-learning to improve the model's performance over time.

7. Ethical Considerations: Consider the ethical implications of your model's use and potential misuse. Develop policies and guidelines for the responsible use of your model and engage with stakeholders to ensure that your model is used in a socially responsible manner.

Directive 2014/53/EU, also known as the Radio Equipment Directive (RED), is a regulation that sets out the requirements for radio equipment to be sold in the European Union (EU). Its purpose is to ensure that radio equipment placed on the EU market meets certain safety and performance standards, and to harmonize the rules for radio equipment across the EU.

As a tech startup marketing radio equipment in the EU, you must comply with the RED if your products fall within its scope. This includes any equipment that uses the radio spectrum to transmit or receive signals, such as Wi-Fi routers, Bluetooth devices, and mobile phones.

To comply with the RED, you must ensure that your radio equipment meets the essential requirements set out in the directive, such as safety, electromagnetic compatibility, and efficient use of the radio spectrum. You must also ensure that your equipment is properly labeled with the CE mark and other required information, and that you have a technical file documenting your compliance with the directive.

Failure to comply with the RED can result in serious consequences, including fines, product recalls, and damage to your reputation. It is important to work with a qualified testing and certification body to ensure that your radio equipment meets the requirements of the directive and to minimize your compliance risks.

question: As a project leader focused on socially beneficial AI, what principles should guide our interdisciplinary cooperation to ensure effective outcomes?
reference_answer: Such projects should be based on the principle of interdisciplinary cooperation between AI developers, experts on inequality and non-discrimination, accessibility, consumer, environmental, and digital rights, as well as academics.

inequalities, or meet environmental targets, by allocating sufficient resources, including 
public and Union funding, and, where appropriate and provided that the eligibility and 
selection criteria are fulfilled, considering in particular projects which pursue such 
objectives. Such projects should be based on the principle of interdisciplinary 
cooperation between AI developers, experts on inequality and non-discrimination, 
accessibility, consumer, environmental, and digital rights, as well as academics.

As an AI language model, I do not have personal beliefs or values, but I can provide some principles that can guide interdisciplinary cooperation for effective outcomes in socially beneficial AI projects:

1. Transparency: All stakeholders should have access to information about the project's goals, methods, and outcomes. This includes sharing data, algorithms, and decision-making processes.

2. Inclusivity: The project should involve diverse perspectives and voices, including those of marginalized communities, to ensure that the technology is designed to benefit everyone.

3. Ethical considerations: The project should prioritize ethical considerations, such as privacy, fairness, and accountability, to ensure that the technology is used for the greater good.

4. Continuous learning: The project should be open to feedback and learning from mistakes to improve the technology and its impact on society.

5. Collaboration: The project should involve collaboration between experts from different fields, including computer science, social sciences, and humanities, to ensure that the technology is designed with a holistic understanding of its impact on society.

6. Human-centered design: The project should prioritize the needs and values of humans, rather than solely focusing on technological advancements.

7. Sustainability: The project should consider the long-term impact of the technology on society and the environment, and strive to create sustainable solutions.

question: As a provider of general-purpose AI models, who specifically supervises and enforces Chapter V, and what implications does this have for my compliance efforts?
reference_answer: The Commission shall have exclusive powers to supervise and enforce Chapter V.
reference_context:

Article 88
Enforcement of the obligations of providers of general-purpose AI models
1.
The Commission shall have exclusive powers to supervise and enforce Chapter V, taking 
into account the procedural guarantees under Article 94. The Commission shall entrust 
the implementation of these tasks to the AI Office, without prejudice to the powers of 
organisation of the Commission and the division of competences between Member States 
and the Union based on the Treaties.
2.
Without prejudice to Article 75(3), market surveillance authorities may request the 
Commission to exercise the powers laid down in this Section, where that is necessary 
and proportionate to assist with the fulfilment of their tasks under this Regulation.
agent_answer:
Chapter V of the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) pertains to the transfer of personal data to third countries or international organizations. As a provider of general-purpose AI models, you may be transferring personal data to third countries or international organizations, which means you are subject to the provisions of Chapter V.

The supervisory authority responsible for enforcing Chapter V depends on your location and the location of the data subjects whose personal data you are processing. If you are based in the European Union (EU), you will be subject to the supervision of the data protection authority in your member state. If you are based outside the EU, you may be subject to the supervision of the data protection authority in the EU member state where your customers are located.

To comply with Chapter V, you must ensure that any transfer of personal data to third countries or international organizations is done in accordance with the GDPR's requirements. This may involve implementing appropriate safeguards, such as standard contractual clauses or binding corporate rules, or obtaining explicit consent from the data subjects.

Overall, compliance with Chapter V requires careful attention to the specific requirements of the GDPR and the guidance provided by the relevant supervisory authorities. As a provider of general-purpose AI models, you should work closely with legal and compliance experts to ensure that your data processing activities are fully compliant with the GDPR and other applicable data protection laws.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer incorrectly states that the supervisory authority depends on the provider's location, while the ground truth specifies that the Commission has exclusive powers to supervise and enforce Chapter V.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides relevant information about Chapter V and its implications for compliance but does not explicitly state that the Commission has exclusive powers to supervise and enforce it, leading to minor inaccuracies.

question: As a business affected by this Regulation, can you clarify its main objective regarding AI and how it impacts my operations?
reference_answer: The objective of this Regulation is to improve the functioning of the internal market and to promote the uptake of human centric and trustworthy AI, while ensuring a high level of protection of health, safety, fundamental rights, including democracy, the rule of law and environmental protection against harmful effects of AI systems in the Union and supporting innovation.

implementing powers should be conferred on the Commission. Those powers should be 
exercised in accordance with Regulation (EU) No 182/2011 of the European Parliament 
and of the Council56.
(176)
Since the objective of this Regulation, namely to improve the functioning of the internal 
market and to promote the uptake of human centric and trustworthy AI, while ensuring a 
high level of protection of health, safety, fundamental rights enshrined in the Charter, 
including democracy, the rule of law and environmental protection against harmful effects 
of AI systems in the Union and supporting innovation, cannot be sufficiently achieved by 
the Member States and can rather, by reason of the scale or effects of the action, be better 
achieved at Union level, the Union may adopt measures in accordance with the principle of 
subsidiarity as set out in Article 5 TEU. In accordance with the principle of proportionality 
as set out in that Article, this Regulation does not go beyond what is necessary in order to 
achieve that objective.

control by Member States of the Commission’s exercise of implementing powers (OJ L 55, 
28.2.2011, p. 13).
agent_answer:
The main objective of the Regulation on a European approach for Artificial Intelligence (AI) is to ensure that AI is developed and used in a way that is safe, trustworthy, and respects fundamental rights and values. The Regulation aims to establish a harmonized legal framework for AI across the European Union (EU) and to promote innovation and competitiveness in the field of AI.

The Regulation will impact your operations if you develop, deploy, or use AI systems in the EU. It will require you to comply with certain requirements, such as ensuring that your AI systems are transparent, explainable, and auditable. You will also need to conduct risk assessments and implement appropriate measures to mitigate any risks associated with your AI systems.

Additionally, the Regulation will prohibit certain uses of AI that are considered high-risk, such as those that could result in physical or psychological harm to individuals, or that could be used to manipulate people's behavior in a way that is detrimental to their rights and freedoms.

Overall, the Regulation aims to create a level playing field for AI in the EU, while also ensuring that AI is developed and used in a way that is ethical and respects human rights.

question: What is the role of notifying authorities in ensuring objectivity and impartiality, and what specific requirements must they meet regarding their personnel?
reference_answer: Notifying authorities play a crucial role in maintaining objectivity and impartiality, ensuring that no conflict of interest arises with conformity assessment bodies. They must also have a sufficient number of competent personnel to effectively perform their tasks, thereby supporting their role in safeguarding the integrity of their activities.
reference_context:

EN

paragraph 1 is to be carried out by a national accreditation body within the meaning of, 
and in accordance with, Regulation (EC) No 765/2008 ▌ .
3.
Notifying authorities shall be established, organised and operated in such a way that no 
conflict of interest arises with conformity assessment bodies, and that the objectivity and 
impartiality of their activities are safeguarded.
4.
Notifying authorities shall be organised in such a way that decisions relating to the 
notification of conformity assessment bodies are taken by competent persons different 
from those who carried out the assessment of those bodies.
5.
Notifying authorities shall offer or provide neither any activities that conformity 
assessment bodies perform, nor any consultancy services on a commercial or competitive 
basis.
6.
Notifying authorities shall safeguard the confidentiality of the information that they obtain, 
in accordance with Article 78.
7.
Notifying authorities shall have an adequate number of competent personnel at their 
disposal for the proper performance of their tasks. Competent personnel shall have the 
necessary expertise, where applicable, for their function, in fields such as information 
technologies, AI and law, including the supervision of fundamental rights.

question: What actions should operators of high-risk AI systems take if their systems change significantly after the Regulation's application date, and how does this relate to the encouragement for providers to comply during the transitional period?
reference_answer: Operators of high-risk AI systems must ensure compliance with the Regulation only if significant changes occur after the application date, while providers are encouraged to voluntarily start complying with the Regulation during the transitional period. This highlights a proactive approach for providers, while operators must assess their systems' changes to determine compliance obligations.

have been placed on the market or put into service before the general date of application 
thereof, only if, from that date, those systems are subject to significant changes in their 
design or intended purpose. It is appropriate to clarify that, in this respect, the concept of 
significant change should be understood as equivalent in substance to the notion of

basis, with the relevant obligations of this Regulation already during the transitional 
period.

question: What are the conditions for a software or data model to be classified as free and open-source under the EU AI Act, and what transparency obligations do providers of general-purpose AI models have when released under such a licence?
reference_answer: To be considered free and open-source under the EU AI Act, a software or data model must allow users to run, copy, distribute, study, change, and improve it, while crediting the original provider and respecting distribution terms. Additionally, providers of general-purpose AI models must produce a summary of the training content and ensure compliance with Union copyright law, highlighting the importance of both licensing conditions and transparency in fostering responsible AI usage.
reference_context:
Document 104: EN
United in diversity
EN
(102)
Software and data, including models, released under a free and open-source licence that 
allows them to be openly shared and where users can freely access, use, modify and 
redistribute them or modified versions thereof, can contribute to research and 
innovation in the market and can provide significant growth opportunities for the Union 
economy. General-purpose AI models released under free and open-source licences 
should be considered to ensure high levels of transparency and openness if their 
parameters, including the weights, the information on the model architecture, and the 
information on model usage are made publicly available. The licence should be 
considered to be free and open-source also when it allows users to run, copy, distribute, 
study, change and improve software and data, including models under the condition that 
the original provider of the model is credited, the identical or comparable terms of 
distribution are respected. 
(103)
Free and open-source AI components covers the software and data, including models 
and general-purpose AI models, tools, services or processes of an AI system. Free and 
open-source AI components can be provided through different channels, including their 
development on open repositories. For the purposes of this Regulation, AI components 
that are provided against a price or otherwise monetised, including through the 
provision of technical support or other services, including through a software platform, 
related to the AI component, or the use of personal data for reasons other than 
exclusively for improving the security, compatibility or interoperability of the software, 
with the exception of transactions between microenterprises, should not benefit from the 
exceptions provided to free and open-source AI components. The fact of making AI 
components available through open repositories should not, in itself, constitute a 
monetisation.

Document 105: EN
United in diversity
EN

The providers of general-purpose AI models that are released under a free and open-
source licence, and whose parameters, including the weights, the information on the 
model architecture, and the information on model usage, are made publicly available 
should be subject to exceptions as regards the transparency-related requirements 
imposed on general-purpose AI models, unless they can be considered to present a 
systemic risk, in which case the circumstance that the model is transparent and 
accompanied by an open-source license should not be considered to be a sufficient 
reason to exclude compliance with the obligations under this Regulation. In any case, 
given that the release of general-purpose AI models under free and open-source licence 
does not necessarily reveal substantial information on the data set used for the training 
or fine-tuning of the model and on how compliance of copyright law was thereby 
ensured, the exception provided for general-purpose AI models from compliance with 
the transparency-related requirements should not concern the obligation to produce a 
summary about the content used for model training and the obligation to put in place a 
policy to comply with Union copyright law, in particular to identify and comply with the 
reservation of rights pursuant to Article 4(3) of Directive (EU) 2019/790 of the 
European Parliament and of the Council40.

The EU AI Act defines free and open-source software or data models as those that meet the following conditions:

1. The software or data model must be licensed under an open-source license approved by the Open Source Initiative or the Free Software Foundation.

2. The source code or data model must be made available to the public, either through a publicly accessible repository or by providing it upon request.

3. The software or data model must be free to use, modify, and distribute without any restrictions on who can use it or how it can be used.

4. The license must not discriminate against any person or group of persons.

Providers of general-purpose AI models that are released under a free and open-source license have transparency obligations under the EU AI Act. They must provide clear and comprehensive documentation that describes the functionality, limitations, and potential risks associated with the model. They must also provide information on the data used to train the model, including its quality, diversity, and representativeness. Additionally, they must provide information on any biases or limitations in the data or model that could affect its performance or accuracy. Finally, they must provide ongoing support and maintenance for the model, including updates and bug fixes.

The agent's response lacks mention of these critical aspects.

question: How do Member States utilize the experts of the scientific panel according to Article 69, and what role does the Commission play in facilitating access to these experts?
reference_answer: Member States can call upon the experts of the scientific panel to support their enforcement activities, while the Commission plays a crucial role by facilitating timely access to these experts as needed. This collaboration ensures that Member States have the necessary expertise to effectively implement regulations.
reference_context:
Document 351: EN
United in diversity
EN
Article 69
Access to the pool of experts by the Member States
1.
Member States may call upon experts of the scientific panel to support their enforcement 
activities under this Regulation.
2.
The Member States may be required to pay fees for the advice and support provided by 
the experts. The structure and the level of fees as well as the scale and structure of 
recoverable costs shall be set out in the implementing act referred to in Article 68(1), 
taking into account the objectives of the adequate implementation of this Regulation, 
cost-effectiveness and the necessity of ensuring effective access to experts for all 
Member States.
3.
The Commission shall facilitate timely access to the experts by the Member States, as 
needed, and ensure that the combination of support activities carried out by Union AI 
testing support pursuant to Article 84 and experts pursuant to this Article is efficiently 
organised and provides the best possible added value.

agent_answer:
According to Article 69 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU), Member States can utilize the experts of the scientific panel in several ways. These include:

1. Seeking advice: Member States can request advice from the scientific panel on matters related to the environment, public health, and consumer protection.

2. Providing information: Member States can provide information to the scientific panel on matters related to the environment, public health, and consumer protection.

3. Participating in the work of the panel: Member States can participate in the work of the scientific panel by providing experts or by attending meetings.

The Commission plays a role in facilitating access to these experts by:

1. Coordinating the work of the scientific panel: The Commission is responsible for coordinating the work of the scientific panel and ensuring that its activities are consistent with EU policies and objectives.

2. Providing funding: The Commission provides funding for the scientific panel's activities, including research, studies, and expert advice.

3. Facilitating communication: The Commission facilitates communication between the scientific panel and Member States by providing a platform for exchange of information and expertise.

Overall, the Commission plays a crucial role in ensuring that Member States have access to the expertise of the scientific panel and that their input is taken into account in the panel's work.

question: What obligations do employers have in informing workers about AI systems, and why is this information requirement particularly necessary for high-risk AI systems?
reference_answer: Employers are obligated to inform or consult workers about AI systems under Union or national law, including Directive 2002/14/EC, to ensure transparency and protect workers' rights. This information requirement is especially crucial for high-risk AI systems as it safeguards fundamental rights and ensures that workers and their representatives are aware of potential impacts on their work environment.
reference_context:

and consult workers or their representatives under Union or national law and practice, 
including Directive 2002/14/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council39, on 
decisions to put into service or use AI systems. It remains necessary to ensure 
information of workers and their representatives on the planned deployment of high-risk 
AI systems at the workplace where the conditions for those information or information 
and consultation obligations in other legal instruments are not fulfilled. Moreover, such 
information right is ancillary and necessary to the objective of protecting fundamental 
rights that underlies this Regulation. Therefore, an information requirement to that 
effect should be laid down in this Regulation, without affecting any existing rights of 
workers.

Employers have an obligation to inform workers about AI systems because it affects their work and job security. Workers need to know how AI systems are being used, what data is being collected, and how it is being used. This information requirement is particularly necessary for high-risk AI systems because they have the potential to cause harm to workers or the public. 

High-risk AI systems, such as those used in healthcare, transportation, and finance, can have serious consequences if they malfunction or are used improperly. For example, an AI system used in healthcare that makes incorrect diagnoses or treatment recommendations could harm patients. Similarly, an AI system used in transportation that fails to detect hazards could cause accidents. 

Workers need to be informed about high-risk AI systems so that they can understand the risks and take appropriate precautions. They also need to be trained on how to use the systems properly and how to respond in case of a malfunction. Employers have a responsibility to provide this information and training to ensure the safety of their workers and the public.

tools, services, components, or processes that are used or integrated in a high-risk AI 
system shall, by written agreement, specify the necessary information, capabilities, 
technical access and other assistance based on the generally acknowledged state of the 
art, in order to enable the provider of the high-risk AI system to fully comply with the 
obligations set out in this Regulation. This paragraph shall not apply to third parties 
making accessible to the public tools, services, processes, or components, other than 
general-purpose AI models, under a free and open-source licence.

To ensure legal certainty, it is necessary to clarify that, under certain specific conditions, 
any distributor, importer, deployer or other third-party should be considered to be a 
provider of a high-risk AI system and therefore assume all the relevant obligations. This 
would be the case if that party puts its name or trademark on a high-risk AI system 
already placed on the market or put into service, without prejudice to contractual 
arrangements stipulating that the obligations are allocated otherwise. This would also be 
the case if that party makes a substantial modification to a high-risk AI system that has 
already been placed on the market or has already been put into service in a way that it 
remains a high-risk AI system in accordance with this Regulation, or if it modifies the 
intended purpose of an AI system, including a general-purpose AI system, which has not 
been classified as high-risk and has already been placed on the market or put into 
service, in a way that the AI system becomes a high-risk AI system in accordance with 
this Regulation. Those provisions should apply without prejudice to more specific 
provisions established in certain Union harmonisation legislation based on the New 
Legislative Framework, together with which this Regulation should apply. For example, 
Article 16(2) of Regulation (EU) 2017/745, establishing that certain changes should not 
be considered to be modifications of a device that could affect its compliance with the 
applicable requirements, should continue to apply to high-risk AI systems that are 
medical devices within the meaning of that Regulation.

CHAPTER III
HIGH-RISK AI SYSTEMS
Section 1
Classification of AI systems as high-risk
Article 6
Classification rules for high-risk AI systems
1.
Irrespective of whether an AI system is placed on the market or put into service 
independently of the products referred to in points (a) and (b), that AI system shall be 
considered to be high-risk where both of the following conditions are fulfilled:

High-risk AI systems should only be placed on the Union market, put into service or used 
if they comply with certain mandatory requirements. Those requirements should ensure 
that high-risk AI systems available in the Union or whose output is otherwise used in the 
Union do not pose unacceptable risks to important Union public interests as recognised and

the Commission notice “The ‘Blue Guide’ on the implementation of EU product rules

burdens or costs, providers of a product that contains one or more high-risk AI systems, 
to which the requirements of this Regulation and of the Union harmonisation legislation 
listed in an annex to this Regulation apply, should have flexibility with regard to 
operational decisions on how to ensure compliance of a product that contains one or 
more AI systems with all applicable requirements of the Union harmonisation legislation 
in an optimal manner. AI systems identified as high-risk should be limited to those that 
have a significant harmful impact on the health, safety and fundamental rights of persons 
in the Union and such limitation should minimise any potential restriction to international 
trade.

agent_answer:
The conditions that define a product manufacturer as the provider of a high-risk AI system are:

1. The AI system is intended to be used as a safety component of a product, or as a product itself.
2. The AI system is capable of making decisions that significantly affect the safety and fundamental rights of individuals.
3. The AI system is used in critical infrastructure sectors such as healthcare, transportation, energy, and finance.

The mandatory requirements for high-risk AI systems in the Union are:

1. Risk assessment: The manufacturer must conduct a risk assessment to identify potential risks associated with the AI system and take measures to mitigate them.

2. Technical documentation: The manufacturer must provide technical documentation that describes the AI system's design, development, and operation.

3. Transparency: The manufacturer must ensure that the AI system's decision-making process is transparent and explainable.

4. Human oversight: The manufacturer must ensure that the AI system is subject to human oversight and control.

5. Accuracy and reliability: The manufacturer must ensure that the AI system is accurate, reliable, and performs as intended.

6. Data quality: The manufacturer must ensure that the data used to train and operate the AI system is of high quality and unbiased.

7. Cybersecurity: The manufacturer must ensure that the AI system is secure and protected against cyber threats.

8. Compliance with ethical principles: The manufacturer must ensure that the AI system complies with ethical principles, including respect for human dignity, privacy, and autonomy.

The agent's response lacks the core definition of a provider and does not align with the broader context of safety standards.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides relevant information about high-risk AI systems but includes some inaccuracies regarding the definition of a product manufacturer as the provider, and it lacks a direct mention of accountability, which is a key aspect of the reference answer.

question: What is the purpose of applying the rules established by the Regulation to AI system providers, and why is it important to maintain a consistent level of protection for these systems throughout the Union?
reference_answer: The purpose of applying the Regulation's rules to AI system providers is to ensure a level playing field and protect individual rights across the Union, while maintaining a consistent level of protection is crucial for fostering trustworthy AI and preventing divergences that could disrupt the internal market. Together, these objectives promote innovation and the effective deployment of AI systems throughout the Union.
reference_context:
Document 22: EN
United in diversity
EN
(21)
In order to ensure a level playing field and an effective protection of rights and freedoms of 
individuals across the Union, the rules established by this Regulation should apply to 
providers of AI systems in a non-discriminatory manner, irrespective of whether they are 
established within the Union or in a third country, and to deployers of AI systems 
established within the Union.
(22)
In light of their digital nature, certain AI systems should fall within the scope of this 
Regulation even when they are not placed on the market, put into service, or used in the 
Union. This is the case, for example, where an operator established in the Union contracts 
certain services to an operator established in a third country in relation to an activity to be 
performed by an AI system that would qualify as high-risk ▌ . In those circumstances, the 
AI system used in a third country by the operator could process data lawfully collected in 
and transferred from the Union, and provide to the contracting operator in the Union the 
output of that AI system resulting from that processing, without that AI system being 
placed on the market, put into service or used in the Union. To prevent the circumvention 
of this Regulation and to ensure an effective protection of natural persons located in the 
Union, this Regulation should also apply to providers and deployers of AI systems that are 
established in a third country, to the extent the output produced by those systems is 
intended to be used in the Union.

Document 3: EN
United in diversity
EN
(3)
▌ AI systems ▌ can be easily deployed in a large variety of sectors of the economy and 
many parts of society, including across borders, and can easily circulate throughout the 
Union. Certain Member States have already explored the adoption of national rules to 
ensure that AI is trustworthy and safe and is developed and used in accordance with 
fundamental rights obligations. Diverging national rules may lead to the fragmentation of 
the internal market and may decrease legal certainty for operators that develop, import or 
use AI systems. A consistent and high level of protection throughout the Union should 
therefore be ensured in order to achieve trustworthy AI, while divergences hampering the 
free circulation, innovation, deployment and the uptake of AI systems and related 
products and services within the internal market should be prevented by laying down 
uniform obligations for operators and guaranteeing the uniform protection of overriding 
reasons of public interest and of rights of persons throughout the internal market on the 
basis of Article 114 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU). To 
the extent that this Regulation contains specific rules on the protection of individuals with 
regard to the processing of personal data concerning restrictions of the use of AI systems 
for remote biometric identification for the purpose of law enforcement, of the use of AI 
systems for risk assessments of natural persons for the purpose of law enforcement and 
of the use of AI systems of biometric categorisation for the purpose of law enforcement, it 
is appropriate to base this Regulation, in so far as those specific rules are concerned, on 
Article 16 TFEU. In light of those specific rules and the recourse to Article 16 TFEU, it is 
appropriate to consult the European Data Protection Board.

This includes ensuring that AI systems are designed to be robust, reliable, and secure, and that they are subject to appropriate human oversight.

Maintaining a consistent level of protection for AI systems throughout the Union is important because it ensures that all users of AI systems are subject to the same standards and protections, regardless of where they are located. This helps to promote trust in AI systems and ensures that they are used in a way that is consistent with the values and principles of the European Union. It also helps to prevent a race to the bottom in terms of AI regulation, where companies may seek to locate in countries with weaker regulations in order to avoid compliance costs.

question: What is the purpose of the advisory forum established under this Regulation and who is responsible for appointing its members?
reference_answer: The purpose of the advisory forum is to advise and provide technical expertise to the Board and the Commission, while the Commission is responsible for appointing the members of the forum according to specified criteria. This highlights the forum's role in supporting the Commission with expert advice, and the Commission's authority in its composition.
reference_context:
Document 147: EN
United in diversity
EN
(150)
With a view to ensuring the involvement of stakeholders in the implementation and 
application of this Regulation, an advisory forum should be established to advise and 
provide technical expertise to the Board and the Commission. To ensure a varied and 
balanced stakeholder representation between commercial and non-commercial interest 
and, within the category of commercial interests, with regards to SMEs and other 
undertakings, the advisory forum should comprise inter alia industry, start-ups, SMEs, 
academia, civil society, including the social partners, as well as the Fundamental Rights 
Agency, ENISA, the European Committee for Standardization (CEN), the European 
Committee for Electrotechnical Standardization (CENELEC) and the European 
Telecommunications Standards Institute (ETSI).
(151)
To support the implementation and enforcement of this Regulation, in particular the 
monitoring activities of the AI Office as regards general-purpose AI models, a scientific 
panel of independent experts should be established. The independent experts 
constituting the scientific panel should be selected on the basis of up-to-date scientific or 
technical expertise in the field of AI and should perform their tasks with impartiality, 
objectivity and ensure the confidentiality of information and data obtained in carrying 
out their tasks and activities. To allow the reinforcement of national capacities necessary 
for the effective enforcement of this Regulation, Member States should be able to request 
support from the pool of experts constituting the scientific panel for their enforcement 
activities.

receive opinions by the Member States on qualified alerts regarding general-purpose AI

Article 67
Advisory forum
1.
An advisory forum shall be established to provide technical expertise and advise the 
Board and the Commission, and to contribute to their tasks under this Regulation.
2.
The membership of the advisory forum shall represent a balanced selection of 
stakeholders, including industry, start-ups, SMEs, civil society and academia. The 
membership of the advisory forum shall be balanced with regard to commercial and 
non-commercial interests and, within the category of commercial interests, with regard 
to SMEs and other undertakings.
3.
The Commission shall appoint the members of the advisory forum, in accordance with 
the criteria set out in paragraph 2, from amongst stakeholders with recognised expertise 
in the field of AI.

question: What is the purpose of processing personal data in AI regulatory sandboxes, and what compliance requirements must this processing meet?
reference_answer: The purpose of processing personal data in AI regulatory sandboxes is to prevent, investigate, detect, or prosecute criminal offenses and ensure public security. This processing must comply with specific Union or national laws and adhere to the same cumulative conditions, ensuring that it is both lawful and aligned with regulatory standards.

shall be based on a specific Union or national law and subject to the same cumulative 
conditions as referred to in paragraph 1.

personal data for other purposes than those explicitly mentioned in that law, as well as to

any other legal basis, in compliance with Union law on the protection of personal data.

question: What rights or obligations remain unchanged by Paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 in relation to the definition of AI systems presenting a risk under EU regulations?
reference_answer: Paragraphs 1, 2, and 3 do not affect the rights or obligations of the Commission, Member States, and their authorities concerning information exchange and warnings, while AI systems presenting a risk are defined as 'products presenting a risk' under Article 3, point 19 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1020. This highlights that while certain obligations remain intact, the definition of risk in AI systems is a separate regulatory concern.

cross-border cooperation, nor shall they affect the obligations of the parties concerned to 
provide information under criminal law of the Member States.
5.
The Commission and Member States may exchange, where necessary and in accordance 
with relevant provisions of international and trade agreements, confidential information 
with regulatory authorities of third countries with which they have concluded bilateral or 
multilateral confidentiality arrangements guaranteeing an adequate level of confidentiality.

in Article 3, point 19 of Regulation (EU) 2019/1020, in so far as they present risks to the 
health or safety, or to ▌ fundamental rights, of persons.

question: What are the classifications of high-risk AI systems in critical infrastructure management, and how do safety components relate to these classifications?
reference_answer: High-risk AI systems in critical infrastructure management are those designed to serve as safety components, which are specifically aimed at protecting the physical integrity of the infrastructure and ensuring the health and safety of individuals and property. Therefore, safety components are integral to the classification of these AI systems, as they directly influence the risk assessment based on their role in safeguarding critical infrastructure.
reference_context:
Document 62: EN
United in diversity
EN
(55)
As regards the management and operation of critical infrastructure, it is appropriate to 
classify as high-risk the AI systems intended to be used as safety components in the 
management and operation of critical digital infrastructure as listed in point (8) of the 
Annex to Directive (EU) 2022/2557, road traffic and the supply of water, gas, heating and 
electricity, since their failure or malfunctioning may put at risk the life and health of 
persons at large scale and lead to appreciable disruptions in the ordinary conduct of social 
and economic activities. Safety components of critical infrastructure, including critical 
digital infrastructure, are systems used to directly protect the physical integrity of critical 
infrastructure or the health and safety of persons and property but which are not 
necessary in order for the system to function. The failure or malfunctioning of such 
components might directly lead to risks to the physical integrity of critical infrastructure 
and thus to risks to health and safety of persons and property. Components intended to 
be used solely for cybersecurity purposes should not qualify as safety components. 
Examples of safety components of such critical infrastructure may include systems for 
monitoring water pressure or fire alarm controlling systems in cloud computing centres.
metadata: {'question_type': 'compare', 'original_questions': [{'question': 'What AI systems are classified as high-risk in the management of critical infrastructure?', 'answer': 'AI systems intended to be used as safety components in the management and operation of critical digital infrastructure are classified as high-risk.'}, {'question': 'What are safety components of critical infrastructure?', 'answer': 'Safety components of critical infrastructure are systems used to directly protect the physical integrity of critical infrastructure or the health and safety of persons and property.'}], 'seed_document_id': 62, 'topic': 'High-Risk AI Systems'}
agent_answer:
There are several classifications of high-risk AI systems in critical infrastructure management, including:

1. Autonomous systems: These are AI systems that operate without human intervention and are responsible for critical infrastructure management tasks such as power grid management, water treatment, and transportation systems.

2. Decision support systems: These are AI systems that provide recommendations to human operators in critical infrastructure management tasks such as emergency response and disaster management.

3. Predictive maintenance systems: These are AI systems that use data analytics to predict equipment failures and maintenance needs in critical infrastructure systems.

4. Cybersecurity systems: These are AI systems that detect and respond to cyber threats in critical infrastructure systems.

Safety components are essential in all of these classifications of high-risk AI systems. Safety components ensure that the AI systems operate within safe parameters and do not pose a risk to human operators or the critical infrastructure systems they manage. Safety components may include fail-safe mechanisms, redundancy systems, and real-time monitoring and control systems. The safety components must be designed and implemented to ensure that the AI systems operate safely and effectively in critical infrastructure management.
correctness_reason: The agent's answer provides classifications of high-risk AI systems but does not accurately reflect the relationship between these classifications and safety components as described in the ground truth. The ground truth emphasizes that high-risk AI systems are designed to serve as safety components, which is not addressed in the agent's response.
reason_method2: The generated answer provides a detailed classification of high-risk AI systems but lacks a clear connection to how safety components specifically relate to these classifications, leading to partial correctness.

Providers of high-risk AI systems must therefore comply with both the requirements under Union harmonisation legislation and the additional requirements under Section 2 of the EU AI Act. question: What actions should a provider take if their general-purpose AI model is classified as having systemic risks, and how does the Commission determine this designation?
reference_answer: If a provider's general-purpose AI model meets the criteria for systemic risks, they must notify the AI Office within two weeks. The Commission designates a model as having systemic risk based on its capabilities or impact reaching a specific threshold, reflecting a regulatory approach that considers both provider responsibilities and the Commission's evaluative criteria.
reference_context:
Document 113: EN
United in diversity
EN
(112)
It is also necessary to clarify a procedure for the classification of a general-purpose AI 
model with systemic risks. A general-purpose AI model that meets the applicable 
threshold for high-impact capabilities should be presumed to be a general-purpose AI 
models with systemic risk. The provider should notify the AI Office at the latest two 
weeks after the requirements are met or it becomes known that a general-purpose AI 
model will meet the requirements that lead to the presumption. This is especially relevant 
in relation to the threshold of floating point operations because training of general-
purpose AI models takes considerable planning which includes the upfront allocation of 
compute resources and, therefore, providers of general-purpose AI models are able to 
know if their model would meet the threshold before the training is completed. In the 
context of that notification, the provider should be able to demonstrate that, because of 
its specific characteristics, a general-purpose AI model exceptionally does not present 
systemic risks, and that it thus should not be classified as a general-purpose AI model 
with systemic risks. That information is valuable for the AI Office to anticipate the 
placing on the market of general-purpose AI models with systemic risks and the 
providers can start to engage with the AI Office early on. That information is especially 
important with regard to general-purpose AI models that are planned to be released as 
open-source, given that, after the open-source model release, necessary measures to 
ensure compliance with the obligations under this Regulation may be more difficult to 
implement.

Document 111: EN
United in diversity
EN
(111)
It is appropriate to establish a methodology for the classification of general-purpose AI 
models as general-purpose AI model with systemic risks. Since systemic risks result from 
particularly high capabilities, a general-purpose AI model should be considered to 
present systemic risks if it has high-impact capabilities, evaluated on the basis of 
appropriate technical tools and methodologies, or significant impact on the internal 
market due to its reach. High-impact capabilities in general-purpose AI models means 
capabilities that match or exceed the capabilities recorded in the most advanced general-
purpose AI models. The full range of capabilities in a model could be better understood 
after its placing on the market or when deployers interact with the model. According to 
the state of the art at the time of entry into force of this Regulation, the cumulative 
amount of computation used for the training of the general-purpose AI model measured 
in floating point operations is one of the relevant approximations for model capabilities. 
The cumulative amount of computation used for training includes the computation used 
across the activities and methods that are intended to enhance the capabilities of the 
model prior to deployment, such as pre-training, synthetic data generation and fine-
tuning. Therefore, an initial threshold of floating point operations should be set, which, 
if met by a general-purpose AI model, leads to a presumption that the model is a 
general-purpose AI model with systemic risks. This threshold should be adjusted over 
time to reflect technological and industrial changes, such as algorithmic improvements 
or increased hardware efficiency, and should be supplemented with benchmarks and 
indicators for model capability.

Document 112: EN
United in diversity
EN
To inform this, the AI Office should engage with the scientific community, industry, civil 
society and other experts. Thresholds, as well as tools and benchmarks for the 
assessment of high-impact capabilities, should be strong predictors of generality, its 
capabilities and associated systemic risk of general-purpose AI models, and could take 
into account the way the model will be placed on the market or the number of users it 
may affect. To complement this system, there should be a possibility for the Commission 
to take individual decisions designating a general-purpose AI model as a general-
purpose AI model with systemic risk if it is found that such model has capabilities or an 
impact equivalent to those captured by the set threshold. That decision should be taken 
on the basis of an overall assessment of the criteria for the designation of a general-
purpose AI model with systemic risk set out in an annex to this Regulation, such as 
quality or size of the training data set, number of business and end users, its input and 
output modalities, its level of autonomy and scalability, or the tools it has access to. 
Upon a reasoned request of a provider whose model has been designated as a general-
purpose AI model with systemic risk, the Commission should take the request into 
account and may decide to reassess whether the general-purpose AI model can still be 
considered to present systemic risks.

Document 114: EN
United in diversity
EN
(113)
If the Commission becomes aware of the fact that a general-purpose AI model meets the 
requirements to classify as a general-purpose AI model with systemic risk, which 
previously had either not been known or of which the relevant provider has failed to 
notify the Commission, the Commission should be empowered to designate it so. A 
system of qualified alerts should ensure that the AI Office is made aware by the 
scientific panel of general-purpose AI models that should possibly be classified as 
general-purpose AI models with systemic risk, in addition to the monitoring activities of 
the AI Office.
(114)
The providers of general-purpose AI models presenting systemic risks should be subject, 
in addition to the obligations provided for providers of general-purpose AI models, to 
obligations aimed at identifying and mitigating those risks and ensuring an adequate 
level of cybersecurity protection, regardless of whether it is provided as a standalone 
model or embedded in an AI system or a product. To achieve those objectives, this 
Regulation should require providers to perform the necessary model evaluations, in 
particular prior to its first placing on the market, including conducting and documenting 
adversarial testing of models, also, as appropriate, through internal or independent 
external testing. In addition, providers of general-purpose AI models with systemic risks 
should continuously assess and mitigate systemic risks, including for example by putting 
in place risk-management policies, such as accountability and governance processes, 
implementing post-market monitoring, taking appropriate measures along the entire 
model’s lifecycle and cooperating with relevant actors along the AI value chain.

If a provider's general-purpose AI model is classified as having systemic risks, they should take the following actions:

1. Conduct a thorough risk assessment: The provider should conduct a comprehensive risk assessment to identify the potential risks associated with the AI model. This assessment should include an analysis of the model's design, data inputs, and potential impact on users.

2. Mitigate the risks: Once the risks have been identified, the provider should take steps to mitigate them. This may involve modifying the model's design, improving data quality, or implementing additional safeguards to prevent unintended consequences.

3. Monitor the model's performance: The provider should closely monitor the AI model's performance to ensure that it is functioning as intended and that any risks are being effectively managed.

The Commission determines the designation of systemic risks based on a variety of factors, including the potential impact of the AI model on individuals and society as a whole, the likelihood of unintended consequences, and the level of control that users have over the model's outputs. The Commission may also consider the provider's track record in developing and deploying AI models, as well as their willingness to address any identified risks.

question: What are the criteria for reassessing systemic risk in general-purpose AI models, and what obligations do providers have to ensure safety and compliance?
reference_answer: To reassess systemic risk, a provider must submit a reasoned request with new and detailed information since the last decision, while they are also obligated to identify and mitigate risks and maintain adequate cybersecurity measures. Both aspects highlight the importance of ongoing evaluation and proactive risk management in the deployment of general-purpose AI models.

Upon a reasoned request of a provider whose model has been designated as a general-
purpose AI model with systemic risk pursuant to paragraph 4, the Commission shall take 
the request into account and may decide to reassess whether the general-purpose AI 
model can still be considered to present systemic risks on the basis of the criteria set out 
in Annex XIII. Such a request shall contain objective, detailed and new reasons that 
have arisen since the designation decision. Providers may request reassessment at the 
earliest six months after the designation decision. Where the Commission, following its 
reassessment, decides to maintain the designation as a general-purpose AI model with 
systemic risk, providers may request reassessment at the earliest six months after that 
decision.

The Commission shall ensure that a list of general-purpose AI models with systemic risk 
is published and shall keep that list up to date, without prejudice to the need to observe 
and protect intellectual property rights and confidential business information or trade 
secrets in accordance with Union and national law.

The criteria for reassessing systemic risk in general-purpose AI models include:

1. Data quality: The quality of data used to train the AI model should be assessed regularly to ensure that it is accurate, unbiased, and up-to-date.

2. Model performance: The performance of the AI model should be monitored regularly to ensure that it is meeting the desired outcomes and not causing any unintended consequences.

3. Ethical considerations: The AI model should be assessed regularly to ensure that it is not violating any ethical principles or causing harm to individuals or society.

4. Regulatory compliance: The AI model should be assessed regularly to ensure that it is complying with all relevant regulations and standards.

Providers of general-purpose AI models have an obligation to ensure safety and compliance by:

1. Conducting regular risk assessments: Providers should conduct regular risk assessments to identify potential risks and take appropriate measures to mitigate them.

2. Providing transparency: Providers should provide transparency into the AI model's decision-making process and how it is being used.

3. Implementing safety measures: Providers should implement safety measures to prevent unintended consequences and ensure that the AI model is not causing harm.

4. Complying with regulations: Providers should comply with all relevant regulations and standards to ensure that the AI model is safe and compliant.

question: What are the potential adverse impacts of poorly designed high-risk AI systems used by law enforcement authorities, and how do these systems contribute to these risks?
reference_answer: Poorly designed high-risk AI systems, such as those used for assessing crime victim risk or evaluating evidence reliability, can result in unjust surveillance and discrimination, leading to wrongful arrests or loss of liberty. The inherent risks of these systems are amplified when they are not designed with fairness and accountability in mind, potentially exacerbating issues of bias and injustice in law enforcement.
reference_context:
Document 67: EN
United in diversity
EN
(59)
Given their role and responsibility, actions by law enforcement authorities involving 
certain uses of AI systems are characterised by a significant degree of power imbalance 
and may lead to surveillance, arrest or deprivation of a natural person’s liberty as well as 
other adverse impacts on fundamental rights guaranteed in the Charter. In particular, if the 
AI system is not trained with high-quality data, does not meet adequate requirements in 
terms of its performance, its accuracy or robustness, or is not properly designed and tested 
before being put on the market or otherwise put into service, it may single out people in a 
discriminatory or otherwise incorrect or unjust manner. Furthermore, the exercise of 
important procedural fundamental rights, such as the right to an effective remedy and to a 
fair trial as well as the right of defence and the presumption of innocence, could be 
hampered, in particular, where such AI systems are not sufficiently transparent, 
explainable and documented. It is therefore appropriate to classify as high-risk, insofar as 
their use is permitted under relevant Union and national law, a number of AI systems 
intended to be used in the law enforcement context where accuracy, reliability and 
transparency is particularly important to avoid adverse impacts, retain public trust and 
ensure accountability and effective redress.

Document 68: EN
United in diversity
EN
In view of the nature of the activities and the risks relating thereto, those high-risk AI 
systems should include in particular AI systems intended to be used by or on behalf of law 
enforcement authorities or by Union institutions, bodies, offices, or agencies in support of 
law enforcement authorities for assessing the risk of a natural person to become a victim 
of criminal offences, as polygraphs and similar tools, for the evaluation of the reliability 
of evidence in in the course of investigation or prosecution of criminal offences, and, 
insofar as not prohibited under this Regulation, for assessing the risk of a natural 
person offending or reoffending not solely on the basis of the profiling of natural persons 
or the assessment of personality traits and characteristics or the past criminal behaviour of 
natural persons or groups, for profiling in the course of detection, investigation or 
prosecution of criminal offences ▌ . AI systems specifically intended to be used for 
administrative proceedings by tax and customs authorities as well as by financial 
intelligence units carrying out administrative tasks analysing information pursuant to 
Union anti-money laundering law should not be classified as high-risk AI systems used 
by law enforcement authorities for the purpose of prevention, detection, investigation and 
prosecution of criminal offences. The use of AI tools by law enforcement and other 
relevant authorities should not become a factor of inequality, or exclusion. The impact 
of the use of AI tools on the defence rights of suspects should not be ignored, in 
particular the difficulty in obtaining meaningful information on the functioning of those 
systems and the resulting difficulty in challenging their results in court, in particular by 
natural persons under investigation.
